But, the fact that it has gone on for over a year, several years, I just think it's way too drawn out.

I think there are still a lot of societal issues with gender discrimination in the US. It's not just about women; it relates to the specific field of work you're in. For example, I feel women generally face more challenges, because of the “glass ceiling” where even though equality is supposed to exist, many people have a hard time accepting a woman as a leader, especially men. This is due to how society has been raised for so long.

A lot of times in the workplace, women see a job they can qualify for, but maybe the board won’t promote them because historically, women aren’t seen as typically being in leadership positions in business. This also applies to men, like in the fashion industry or for stay-at-home dads. 

It’s not common for a man to stay at home and be the primary caregiver. People often look down on this because society believes men should be the ones working and providing for the family. It can be difficult for these men because maybe it’s always been their dream to be with their children and raise them, and maybe their wife has the better job, and it’s working well for them, but society doesn't approve.

In fashion, straight men aren't always taken seriously. I don’t know if that makes sense, but maybe it's because people associate fashion with being feminine. If a man doesn't fit the typical "masculine" mold and he's in the fashion industry, people might question if he truly understands fashion because it's traditionally seen as a woman's domain.  

Based on the field you work in, I feel like gender discrimination is definitely still present in US society. Changing it is difficult because society has a set mindset. We have come a long way since the 1800s, but change is slow.

I feel that if we continue at this pace, with women rising in positions of power, becoming CEOs, and gaining more acceptance in the business world, things will gradually change. The same goes for stay-at-home dads. As people realize that maybe the female earns more or wants to work, societal attitudes will shift.

It takes time, but there’s progress.

I also think people discriminate against each other based on where they’re from or their background. If you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't perfect, but you're incredibly intelligent and work your way up to a CEO position, people might judge you based on your grammar rather than your skills and intelligence. It's unfair, but it happens.

I think there are still a lot of societal issues with gender discrimination in the US. It's not just about women; it relates to the specific field of work you're in. For example, I feel women generally face more challenges, because of the “glass ceiling” where even though equality is supposed to exist, many people have a hard time accepting a woman as a leader, especially men. This is due to how society has been raised for so long.

A lot of times in the workplace, women see a job they can qualify for, but maybe the board won’t promote them because historically, women aren’t seen as typically being in leadership positions in business. This also applies to men, like in the fashion industry or for stay-at-home dads. 

It’s not common for a man to stay at home and be the primary caregiver. People often look down on this because society believes men should be the ones working and providing for the family. It can be difficult for these men because maybe it’s always been their dream to be with their children and raise them, and maybe their wife has the better job, and it’s working well for them, but society doesn't approve.

In fashion, straight men aren't always taken seriously. I don’t know if that makes sense, but maybe it's because people associate fashion with being feminine. If a man doesn't fit the typical "masculine" mold and he's in the fashion industry, people might question if he truly understands fashion because it's traditionally seen as a woman's domain.  

Based on the field you work in, I feel like gender discrimination is definitely still present in US society. Changing it is difficult because society has a set mindset. We have come a long way since the 1800s, but change is slow.

I feel that if we continue at this pace, with women rising in positions of power, becoming CEOs, and gaining more acceptance in the business world, things will gradually change. The same goes for stay-at-home dads. As people realize that maybe the female earns more or wants to work, societal attitudes will shift.

It takes time, but there’s progress.

I also think people discriminate against each other based on where they’re from or their background. If you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't perfect, but you're incredibly intelligent and work your way up to a CEO position, people might judge you based on your grammar rather than your skills and intelligence. It's unfair, but it happens.

Um, I feel like the war has been dragged on for far too long. I think the purpose was good at the beginning, meaning to restore democracy in another country. But, I think we've long since lost sight of that purpose, and we're now just maybe doing it for the sake of doing it, just to prove that we're some sort of superpower in the world. I just think also maybe the motives were originally questionable, dealing with Um, George Bush's father's previous quarrels with Saddam Hussein. So, I think, Um, I think the original motivation if it was to give democracy to a country that did not have a fair political system, then that would be a fair motivation, if there were any personal matters in it, I don't think it would have been fair. But, I do think it's been dragged out. Um, I think we got our purpose across in the first couple of months, just starting the war, I think that was a statement in and of itself. But, the fact that it has gone on for over a year, several years, I just think it's way too drawn out.

Um, yeah, I think, Um, I mean, if our purpose was to give democracy to a country that was ruled by a tyrant, I think that's a just purpose, and that's a good reason for the war. But, I don't think, I think our reason over time has been deteriorated and misconceived, just like it seems that we're still at war for the purpose of going to war, and we don't want to come out of this thing without a decisive end, a victory or what not.

Health care that I think that money could be much better spent on. We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but, you know, it'll be better than you know where we are, where we stand right now. Um, yeah, uh, no.

I think there are still a lot of societal issues with gender discrimination in the US. It's not just about women; it relates to the specific field of work you're in. For example, I feel women generally face more challenges, because of the “glass ceiling” where even though equality is supposed to exist, many people have a hard time accepting a woman as a leader, especially men. This is due to how society has been raised for so long.

A lot of times in the workplace, women see a job they can qualify for, but maybe the board won’t promote them because historically, women aren’t seen as typically being in leadership positions in business. This also applies to men, like in the fashion industry or for stay-at-home dads. 

It’s not common for a man to stay at home and be the primary caregiver. People often look down on this because society believes men should be the ones working and providing for the family. It can be difficult for these men because maybe it’s always been their dream to be with their children and raise them, and maybe their wife has the better job, and it’s working well for them, but society doesn't approve.

In fashion, straight men aren't always taken seriously. I don’t know if that makes sense, but maybe it's because people associate fashion with being feminine. If a man doesn't fit the typical "masculine" mold and he's in the fashion industry, people might question if he truly understands fashion because it's traditionally seen as a woman's domain.  

Based on the field you work in, I feel like gender discrimination is definitely still present in US society. Changing it is difficult because society has a set mindset. We have come a long way since the 1800s, but change is slow.

I feel that if we continue at this pace, with women rising in positions of power, becoming CEOs, and gaining more acceptance in the business world, things will gradually change. The same goes for stay-at-home dads. As people realize that maybe the female earns more or wants to work, societal attitudes will shift.

It takes time, but there’s progress.

I also think people discriminate against each other based on where they’re from or their background. If you grew up on a farm and your grammar isn't perfect, but you're incredibly intelligent and work your way up to a CEO position, people might judge you based on your grammar rather than your skills and intelligence. It's unfair, but it happens.

The Iraq War

Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war. Before invading Iraq, I think there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality one really didn't have that much to do with the other. But the government made it seem that way and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003.

Um, I myself am pretty much against war, especially to make a preemptive strike. I was against that. Um, and I think that the Iraq War is kind of a repeat in many ways of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes that they have made.

I mean, a tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and that's horrible. What they were doing is that they were taking out, they were removing the country's government, and I really don't think the government, the American government, was prepared for the aftermath and the void of power and the chaos that was going to occur.

Um, and here, the government, and so the United States is removing the Iraqi government, and they are trying to implant a democratic government, and it's kind of a similar thing they were trying to do in Vietnam. They were trying to push out Communists and uphold or implement, implement and uphold democracy. And, and it's, and it's, and the government, and the US government should have known that it was going to be a long and hard ordeal that probably wasn't going to be a clear, clear victory. I mean, it wasn't like it wasn't a clear… I mean, it was more of a loss in Vietnam because, because, um, because there, because there are, there are… no matter how many people may have supported, no matter how many Iraqis may have wanted the US to come in, and no matter how many Vietnamese may have wanted the US to come in, there's going to be a large number of insurgents, and it's hard to put them down when when you're not fighting an actual army. You're fighting the citizens, the specific citizens in the country, and so, so, I think that I think that the government… So, first of all, I think that we shouldn't have gotten into the war because I'm against it in pretty much all cases, and but if you are going to go to war with a country, you need to be prepared for all possible outcomes. I think the government was not as prepared as it should have been.

I mean, they really didn't plan for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government, and I mean we're still there today, almost the end of 2006, and we're still… Um, many American troops are still dying, and they're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and Iraqi police forces to be able to police their own country, and it's a long process, and I just think that that the US government in a way tried to… well, they weren't prepared themselves, but in a way try to deceive the American people in making them think it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq, and I mean we shouldn't, we're kinda naive for believing that because it takes a number of years to implement a new form of government and to and for it to become successful.

I mean, in our own country, democracy was a long struggle, and to be able to get to the powerful government we are today was a long struggle, and there was a lot of tension, and there was civil war, and um, it's just not an easy thing to do, and I think the government, the US government made it seem like a relatively easy thing to do, and um, so, so, let's see.

The Iraq War… well, that's a difficult decision to make because that was kind of my feeling I guess in the election, like the Presidential election of 2004, when I was thinking about who I would vote for if I could vote, and one of um, one of my reasons that I probably would have voted for George Bush was to let him finish what it was that he started, and so I mean once you go in there and we've been in there for so long, how can we abandon these people? I mean, we're the ones that took away their government and their way of life, so how can we abandon them now? So, so it's probably something that we should (coughs) excuse me try to see to its finish, but then again, there's also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties, and and how much is is too much to to to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq.

I mean, going back to the whole reason for invading Iraq, if we're invading Iraq and making it a democratic nation, why is it just Iraq? Why aren't we doing this to all these other countries? And I think the big reason for that is the oil issue, and this is where we are getting our oil from, and it's usually all about money and controlling resources. I mean, because another one of the predispositions was before going into war was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, and no weapons of mass destruction were ever actually found. And yet places like North Korea, we actually knew that they had weapons of mass destruction, and we are not making any attacks against them. So I don't think the US government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions.

Let's see, um, I just hope that it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

Well, I don't think so at all.  Let me see.  My understanding is that MySpace is a public platform, like a bulletin board. So, if you post something online, you have to realize that people will see it, whether it's school officials or not. In my opinion, I think school officials had every right to see it. Even if they weren't doing it under the school's name, they could still access it from home.  But, when it comes to preventing school shootings, you know, as long as it saves lives, which is the school system's responsibility, I think that's perfectly fine. 

Let me think... Like, if they go on MySpace just to see if students are drinking, smoking, or doing other things they shouldn't, they're specifically trying to catch students and get them in trouble. I think that's an invasion of privacy. But, if they're saving lives or making the school a better and safer place, I don't think it's an invasion at all.

Should I elaborate more on that?

Yeah, okay. Well, it's easier to express yourself in writing.

Alright, like I was saying, it's a public thing.  If a student posts something on MySpace without expecting to get in trouble, that's ridiculous. Everything, even emails, worries me. Like, if you do something as a college student and become an important person later on, they might find an old email you sent. Once it's on the internet, it's always there. If you do something, there's no way to get out of it. You will get in trouble. I don't think it was an invasion of privacy because, like I said before, it's a public thing.

Like I said before, I don't think they should go on the internet just to catch students. But if they have something that leads them to make the school system safer, I think that's perfectly fine for them, or even for other officials like the police. Alright, so, I was all for the war at first, because 9/11 personally affected me. I wanted to go over there and create as much havoc as they did here. I think because it was such an emotional event, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't think about the long term. We just kind of went in unprepared and without a plan, and I really think it backfired on us. I don't know, I was all for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I think the people over there, as long as they're fighting amongst themselves, they can't be fighting us too. Like, I don't think us being there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost just stopped caring what goes on over there with those people. I just don't care. I think, I don't think they're human sometimes. I don't know, they fight with each other and can't just do anything themselves. So I really don't care. We definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face over there. It's also bad because war for them is very different than war for us. They're just savage when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out of there, and I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. We were just hyped up, I think. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle and... I just think we went over there looking for revenge, and I think President Bush just went over there because the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. And also, I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. But at the time, I see where he was coming from. We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say, "Okay, let's rebuild," and that's it. So I don't think we could have let it go. But I think we could have just had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't have unity. They didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn. And honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And um, I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. Like, we've made progress, but not enough to stay there. And I think no matter how long we stay there, once we leave, it's just going to collapse. And we can't stay over there forever. The Iraq War

Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war. Before invading Iraq, I think there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality one really didn't have that much to do with the other. But the government made it seem that way and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003.

Um, I myself am pretty much against war, especially to make a preemptive strike. I was against that. Um, and I think that the Iraq War is kind of a repeat in many ways of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes that they have made.

I mean, a tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and that's horrible. What they were doing is that they were taking out, they were removing the country's government, and I really don't think the government, the American government, was prepared for the aftermath and the void of power and the chaos that was going to occur.

Um, and here, the government, and so the United States is removing the Iraqi government, and they are trying to implant a democratic government, and it's kind of a similar thing they were trying to do in Vietnam. They were trying to push out Communists and uphold or implement, implement and uphold democracy. And, and it's, and it's, and the government, and the US government should have known that it was going to be a long and hard ordeal that probably wasn't going to be a clear, clear victory. I mean, it wasn't like it wasn't a clear… I mean, it was more of a loss in Vietnam because, because, um, because there, because there are, there are… no matter how many people may have supported, no matter how many Iraqis may have wanted the US to come in, and no matter how many Vietnamese may have wanted the US to come in, there's going to be a large number of insurgents, and it's hard to put them down when when you're not fighting an actual army. You're fighting the citizens, the specific citizens in the country, and so, so, I think that I think that the government… So, first of all, I think that we shouldn't have gotten into the war because I'm against it in pretty much all cases, and but if you are going to go to war with a country, you need to be prepared for all possible outcomes. I think the government was not as prepared as it should have been.

I mean, they really didn't plan for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government, and I mean we're still there today, almost the end of 2006, and we're still… Um, many American troops are still dying, and they're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and Iraqi police forces to be able to police their own country, and it's a long process, and I just think that that the US government in a way tried to… well, they weren't prepared themselves, but in a way try to deceive the American people in making them think it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq, and I mean we shouldn't, we're kinda naive for believing that because it takes a number of years to implement a new form of government and to and for it to become successful.

I mean, in our own country, democracy was a long struggle, and to be able to get to the powerful government we are today was a long struggle, and there was a lot of tension, and there was civil war, and um, it's just not an easy thing to do, and I think the government, the US government made it seem like a relatively easy thing to do, and um, so, so, let's see.

The Iraq War… well, that's a difficult decision to make because that was kind of my feeling I guess in the election, like the Presidential election of 2004, when I was thinking about who I would vote for if I could vote, and one of um, one of my reasons that I probably would have voted for George Bush was to let him finish what it was that he started, and so I mean once you go in there and we've been in there for so long, how can we abandon these people? I mean, we're the ones that took away their government and their way of life, so how can we abandon them now? So, so it's probably something that we should (coughs) excuse me try to see to its finish, but then again, there's also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties, and and how much is is too much to to to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq.

I mean, going back to the whole reason for invading Iraq, if we're invading Iraq and making it a democratic nation, why is it just Iraq? Why aren't we doing this to all these other countries? And I think the big reason for that is the oil issue, and this is where we are getting our oil from, and it's usually all about money and controlling resources. I mean, because another one of the predispositions was before going into war was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, and no weapons of mass destruction were ever actually found. And yet places like North Korea, we actually knew that they had weapons of mass destruction, and we are not making any attacks against them. So I don't think the US government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions.

Let's see, um, I just hope that it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

Well, I don't think so at all.  Let me see.  My understanding is that MySpace is a public platform, like a bulletin board. If you look at the definition, it's basically for posting things for everyone to see.  So, if you post something online, you have to realize that people will see it, whether it's school officials or not. In my opinion, I think school officials had every right to see it. Even if they weren't doing it under the school's name, they could still access it from home.  But, when it comes to preventing school shootings, you know, as long as it saves lives, which is the school system's responsibility, I think that's perfectly fine. 

Let me think... Like, if they go on MySpace just to see if students are drinking, smoking, or doing other things they shouldn't, they're specifically trying to catch students and get them in trouble. I think that's an invasion of privacy. But, if they're saving lives or making the school a better and safer place, I don't think it's an invasion at all.

Should I elaborate more on that?

Yeah, okay. Well, it's easier to express yourself in writing.

Alright, like I was saying, it's a public thing.  If a student posts something on MySpace without expecting to get in trouble, that's ridiculous. Everything, even emails, worries me. Like, if you do something as a college student and become an important person later on, they might find an old email you sent. Once it's on the internet, it's always there. If you do something, there's no way to get out of it. You will get in trouble. I don't think it was an invasion of privacy because, like I said before, it's a public thing.

Like I said before, I don't think they should go on the internet just to catch students. But if they have something that leads them to make the school system safer, I think that's perfectly fine for them, or even for other officials like the police. Alright, so, I was all for the war at first, because 9/11 personally affected me. I wanted to go over there and create as much havoc as they did here. I think because it was such an emotional event, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't think about the long term. We just kind of went in unprepared and without a plan, and I really think it backfired on us. I don't know, I was all for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I think the people over there, as long as they're fighting amongst themselves, they can't be fighting us too. Like, I don't think us being there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost just stopped caring what goes on over there with those people. I just don't care. I think, I don't think they're human sometimes. I don't know, they fight with each other and can't just do anything themselves. So I really don't care. We definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face over there. It's also bad because war for them is very different than war for us. They're just savage when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out of there, and I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. We were just hyped up, I think. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle and... I just think we went over there looking for revenge, and I think President Bush just went over there because the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. And also, I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. But at the time, I see where he was coming from. We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say, "Okay, let's rebuild," and that's it. So I don't think we could have let it go. But I think we could have just had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't have unity. They didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn. And honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And um, I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. Like, we've made progress, but not enough to stay there. And I think no matter how long we stay there, once we leave, it's just going to collapse. And we can't stay over there forever. The Iraq War

Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for the war. Before invading Iraq, I think there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, when in reality one really didn't have that much to do with the other. But the government made it seem that way and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003.

Um, I myself am pretty much against war, especially to make a preemptive strike. I was against that. Um, and I think that the Iraq War is kind of a repeat in many ways of the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes that they have made.

I mean, a tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and that's horrible. What they were doing is that they were taking out, they were removing the country's government, and I really don't think the government, the American government, was prepared for the aftermath and the void of power and the chaos that was going to occur.

Um, and here, the government, and so the United States is removing the Iraqi government, and they are trying to implant a democratic government, and it's kind of a similar thing they were trying to do in Vietnam. They were trying to push out Communists and uphold or implement, implement and uphold democracy. And, and it's, and it's, and the government, and the US government should have known that it was going to be a long and hard ordeal that probably wasn't going to be a clear, clear victory. I mean, it wasn't like it wasn't a clear… I mean, it was more of a loss in Vietnam because, because, um, because there, because there are, there are… no matter how many people may have supported, no matter how many Iraqis may have wanted the US to come in, and no matter how many Vietnamese may have wanted the US to come in, there's going to be a large number of insurgents, and it's hard to put them down when when you're not fighting an actual army. You're fighting the citizens, the specific citizens in the country, and so, so, I think that I think that the government… So, first of all, I think that we shouldn't have gotten into the war because I'm against it in pretty much all cases, and but if you are going to go to war with a country, you need to be prepared for all possible outcomes. I think the government was not as prepared as it should have been.

I mean, they really didn't plan for what would happen once they removed the Iraqi government, and I mean we're still there today, almost the end of 2006, and we're still… Um, many American troops are still dying, and they're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and Iraqi police forces to be able to police their own country, and it's a long process, and I just think that that the US government in a way tried to… well, they weren't prepared themselves, but in a way try to deceive the American people in making them think it would be a short, successful stay in Iraq, and I mean we shouldn't, we're kinda naive for believing that because it takes a number of years to implement a new form of government and to and for it to become successful.

I mean, in our own country, democracy was a long struggle, and to be able to get to the powerful government we are today was a long struggle, and there was a lot of tension, and there was civil war, and um, it's just not an easy thing to do, and I think the government, the US government made it seem like a relatively easy thing to do, and um, so, so, let's see.

The Iraq War… well, that's a difficult decision to make because that was kind of my feeling I guess in the election, like the Presidential election of 2004, when I was thinking about who I would vote for if I could vote, and one of um, one of my reasons that I probably would have voted for George Bush was to let him finish what it was that he started, and so I mean once you go in there and we've been in there for so long, how can we abandon these people? I mean, we're the ones that took away their government and their way of life, so how can we abandon them now? So, so it's probably something that we should (coughs) excuse me try to see to its finish, but then again, there's also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties, and and how much is is too much to to to keep risking for a free democratic Iraq.

I mean, going back to the whole reason for invading Iraq, if we're invading Iraq and making it a democratic nation, why is it just Iraq? Why aren't we doing this to all these other countries? And I think the big reason for that is the oil issue, and this is where we are getting our oil from, and it's usually all about money and controlling resources. I mean, because another one of the predispositions was before going into war was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, and no weapons of mass destruction were ever actually found. And yet places like North Korea, we actually knew that they had weapons of mass destruction, and we are not making any attacks against them. So I don't think the US government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making their decisions.

Let's see, um, I just hope that it ends soon and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

Well, I don't think so at all.  Let me see.  My understanding is that MySpace is a public platform, like a bulletin board. But, when it comes to preventing school shootings, you know, as long as it saves lives, which is the school system's responsibility, I think that's perfectly fine. 

Let me think... Like, if they go on MySpace just to see if students are drinking, smoking, or doing other things they shouldn't, they're specifically trying to catch students and get them in trouble. Should I elaborate more on that?

Yeah, okay. Well, it's easier to express yourself in writing.

Like, if you do something as a college student and become an important person later on, they might find an old email you sent. Once it's on the internet, it's always there. Alright, so, I was all for the war at first, because 9/11 personally affected me. I wanted to go over there and create as much havoc as they did here. I think because it was such an emotional event, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't think about the long term. We just kind of went in unprepared and without a plan, and I really think it backfired on us. I don't know, I was all for it, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I think the people over there, as long as they're fighting amongst themselves, they can't be fighting us too. Like, I don't think us being there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost just stopped caring what goes on over there with those people. I just don't care. I think, I don't think they're human sometimes. I don't know, they fight with each other and can't just do anything themselves. So I really don't care. We definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face over there. It's also bad because war for them is very different than war for us. They're just savage when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out of there, and I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave and that's really it. We were just hyped up, I think. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle and... I just think we went over there looking for revenge, and I think President Bush just went over there because the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. And also, I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. But at the time, I see where he was coming from. We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say, "Okay, let's rebuild," and that's it. So I don't think we could have let it go. But I think we could have just had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't have unity. They didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn. And honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And um, I really don't have anything else to say. It's gone on long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. Like, we've made progress, but not enough to stay there. And I think no matter how long we stay there, once we leave, it's just going to collapse. And we can't stay over there forever. Okay. The war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war. But the government made it seem that way and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11th, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003.
Um, I, I myself am pretty much against war so, especially to make a preemptive strike, I was against that. I mean it was more of a, it was more of a loss in Vietnam because because, um, because there because there are there are, no matter how many people may have supported, no matter how many Iraqis may have wanted the US to come in and no matter how many Vietnamese may have wanted the US to come in there's going to be a large number of insurgents and its hard to put them down when when you’re not fighting an actual army. You’re fighting the citizens, the specific citizens in the country and so, so I think that I think that the government, so first of all I think that we shouldn't have gotten into into war cause I'm against it in pretty much all cases and but if you are going to go to war with the country you need to be, you need to plan for all possible outcomes. I think the government was not as prepared as it should have been, I mean worst, and either for what would, really not plan for what would happen once once they removed the the Iraqi government and, I mean we’re still there today and almost the end of 2006 and we’re still, um, many American troops are still dying and and they're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and Iraqi, and the Iraqi police forces to be able to police their own country and it’s a long process and I just think that that, that the US government in a way tried to, well they weren’t prepared themselves but in a way try to deceive the American people in making them think it would be a, a, a short successful stay in Iraq and, I mean we shouldn’t, we're kinda, we're naïve for believing that because it takes a number of years to implement a new form of government and to and for it to become successful, I mean in our own country, democracy was a long struggle and to be able to get to the powerful government we are today was a long struggle and there was, there was lots of tension and there was civil war and, um, its just not an easy thing to do and I think the government, the US government made it seem like a relatively easy thing to do and, um, so, and so, let’s see, the war in Iraq. Well, that’s, no that’s, no that’s a difficult decision to make because, that was, well that was kind of my feeling I guess in the election, like the Presidential election of 2004 when I was thinking about who I would vote for if I could vote and one of, um, one of my reasons that I probably would have voted for George Bush was to let him finish what it was that he started and, and so I mean once, its really hard cause once you go in there and we’ve been in there for so long how can we abandon these people, I mean we’re the ones that took away their government and and, and their way of life so how can we abandon them, abandon them now so, so it’s probably something that we should (coughs) excuse me, try to see to its finish but then again there’s also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties and, and, and how, and how much is is too much to to to keep risking for for a free democratic Iraq, I mean, going back to the whole reason for invading Iraq, I mean if we’re, if we’re, if we’re invading Iraq and making it it a democratic nation why is it just Iraq, why aren’t we doing this to all these other countries and I think the big reason for that is, is, is the oil issue, and this is where we are getting our oil from, and it’s usually all about money and controlling resources, I mean because another one of the predispositions is before going into war was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, and no weapons of mass destruction were ever actually found, and yet places like North Korea we actually knew that they had weapons of mass destruction and we are not making any attacks against them, so I don’t think the us government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making there decisions. Let’s see, um, I just hope that it ends soon, and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

I think it's important to remember that marriage equality is a fundamental human right. It's about love, commitment, and the ability to build a family. Denying same-sex couples the right to marry is discriminatory and unjust. 

It's not a matter of personal preference; it's about equality and fairness. There is growing scientific evidence that sexual orientation is a complex interplay of biological and environmental factors, and it's not a choice. 

Marriage is a deeply personal and private matter. It should be celebrated and supported, not dictated by government interference or societal norms. Everyone deserves the right to love and be loved, and to have their relationships recognized and respected.

But the fact that it has gone on for over a year, several years, I just think it's way too drawn out.

Um, yeah, I do think it has gone on long enough, and it should stop. We only have this and then one more time that I need to talk about the Iraq War. I mean I feel hypocritical talking about it, I mean I hate to say, you know, I hate to join the bandwagon of people who are like, "Oh, I was against it from the beginning." And um, I mean you just have to look at like the recent polls. Eighty percent of Iraqis, um, seventy percent of the troops that are over there, like the U.S. troops that are over there right now, think it was a dumb idea and that we should pull out within the year. I feel that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. And it's not only towards women. I feel it has to do with the particular field of work that you're dealing with.  Overall, I feel women have it more difficult because of the glass ceiling. Even though there's supposed to be equality, most people have a hard time finding that they may have to work under a woman if they're a man, just because of how society has been raised for so long. So many times in the workplace, women will see a job they can reach and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't elect to promote them to that position just because historically, it's not seen that women are usually in the upper hands of the business world.  And um, I guess the same thing goes for men. And like other industries like fashion or being a parent at home. It's really uncommon to have a stay-at-home parent who's male. And um, a lot of times people look down upon that because society thinks, well, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the money maker of your family. Why are you staying at home? And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them and maybe the wife has the better job and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down upon that. And then in the fashion industry, um, a lot of times people won't really take males seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion um, like, I guess, have different styles of life. And so if you have the typical style of life and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, well, wait, how do I really know if like you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really don't know what our case is like, like these other guys. And so, depending on like what field of work you're in, I feel like there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. To change it is kind of more difficult because society like has a set mindset and obviously we have come a long way from like the 1800s and leaps and bounds, but change is really slow, so I feel that like if we continue working at the pace we are now because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world and it's a slow process, but it's happening and people are starting to accept it more. And just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, oh wait maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works. And um, then for like fashion people will be like, oh wait maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff, and so they do know like where I'm coming from. So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotypically stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um saying like the qualities of them, because if you force it people are going to resist, and I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that. So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist, and we've come a long ways and change takes time. Yes, um, well I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you go to have yourself like you work your way up into a CEO job even though you might not have the best grammar in the world and or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like well how do I know you're really what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right. So yeah, so like sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don't know, I guess that'd be another example. Um, not really.

I would say yes because a lot of the things they do are very traditional, like they've done the same things for long periods of time, and it's good to be rooted in tradition, but it's also important to be adaptable to change. I guess a lot of Catholics believe they have to go to Church every week, and they're very strict on how things are done. Um, I haven't made up my mind on this issue yet. So, I can't say if either side is right or wrong. But I do believe this is the trickiest topic we're facing today. This is because something so close to the separation of church and state and how to define marriage is very tricky to do without offending anyone. So, I don't know, I think that all civil unions, I don't know whether marriage should be looked at and defined by the government. Seeing as it is a sacrament, like considered... They shouldn't have separation of church and state; they shouldn't look into what kind of marriage it was. Two people got united together. So, and the fact that gay marriage, I mean, that would just... oh, two people you got a civil union.

Um, well, if all the states can come to a logical conclusion, then they should push to make it federal law. But a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is just ridiculous. It is something like the constitution shouldn't just be amended for something. I mean, it is a very big cause for certain people, but it's not large enough that it should be a constitutional amendment.

It's just not important enough to amend the constitution to define to ban gay marriage. Simply put. Uh, no.

I was raised in a Christian home, so homosexuality is kind of a grey area for me. I have a lot of gay friends, and I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, but I think it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but I feel each state should decide for itself rather than the president deciding for the entire country.

A lot of states are democratic and a lot are republican. Obviously, democratic states will push for gay marriage, and if you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about that position. If a state decides to legalize gay marriage, I don't think you're really in a place to disagree with that decision because you kind of chose to live there.

I think homosexuals should be given the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel like it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. 

I kind of already answered that, but I don't think Bush should be allowed to decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to the individual states to decide whether they want to legalize it. I don't agree with his ban on it. I just don't think Bush lives in every single state, so he shouldn't be able to decide how each state wants to run itself. So I think some things should be left up to each individual state. Plus, he's going to be out of office in like two years, and if a democratic president decides that he wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, it's just going to go back and forth. It should just be up to each individual state because they're the ones that are going to have to live with that decision, not the president.

I don't think so at all. Let me see, in my opinion, Myspace is a public thing, like a bulletin board. If you look at the definition, it's basically for posting things for the public to see.  If you post something on the internet, you have to realize that people will see it, whether it's school officials or not.  So, I think the school officials had every right to see it because even if they weren't doing it under the school's name, they could still access it from their homes. But when it comes to preventing school shootings, as long as it saves the lives of students, which is the responsibility of the school system, I think it's perfectly fine.

Let me see. If they go on the internet, like Myspace, just to see if students are drinking, smoking, or doing things they're not supposed to, they're specifically looking to catch students and get them in trouble, and that feels like an invasion of privacy. But if they're trying to save lives or make the school a better and safer place, I don't think it's an invasion at all.

Should I elaborate more on that?

Yeah, okay.  It's easier to express yourself in writing when you have more time.  Like I was saying, it is a public thing.  If a student posts something on Myspace and doesn't expect to get in trouble, that's ridiculous. I'm even worried about posting things on emails. If I have something negative to say about someone, I don't say it in an email because I'm afraid someone might see it. Everything comes back around nowadays.  

Like, if you do something as a college student, and then grow up to be an important person, they might find an email you sent. Once it's on the internet, it's always there, and there's no way to get out of it. You will get in trouble. I don't think it was an invasion of privacy because, like I said before, it's a public thing.

I don't think they should go on the internet just to catch students, but if they have something that leads them to make the school system safer, then I think it's fine. Other officials, like the police, can go on too. Parents drop their students off at school expecting a safe place. I've talked to a teacher about this. They say we have to do things like this because of things like lockdowns and drills, which are in reference to terrorist attacks. We had to be safe, and that kind of relates to school shootings because if someone were to come into the building, we had to be prepared. We practiced these things to make the school safer. That's what the school officials were doing in this case; they were just making it a safer place, preventing something bad from happening, like Columbine.

I think at first I supported the war because of 9/11, because it personally affected me. I was all for going over there and causing as much havoc as they did here. I think because it was such an emotional event, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long run. We kind of just went over there unprepared and without a plan. I really think it backfired on us.  I don't know, I was all for it at the time, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I think the people there, as long as they are fighting amongst themselves, they can't be fighting with us. Like, I don't think us being there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost just become indifferent to what happens over there with those people. I just don't care. I just think sometimes they're not human. I don't know, they fight with each other and they just can't do anything themselves. So I really don't care. We definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face. And it's also bad because war for them is very different than war for us. They're just savage when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out. And I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave, and that's really it. We were just more hype than anything else. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle. We pretty much just went over there looking for revenge, I think, and I think President Bush just went over there because the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. And also, I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. But at the time, I see where he was coming from. We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say ok, let's rebuild and that's it. So, I don't think we could have let it go. But I think we could have had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, like creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't have unity. They didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And I don't really have anything else to say. It's gone on definitely long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. Like we've made progress, but not enough to stay there. And I think no matter how long we stay there, once we leave, it's just gonna collapse. And we can't stay over there forever. So I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying there. No. Ok.

Okay. The war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war. Before invading Iraq, I think there was, I think there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th when in reality one really didn't have that much to do with the other. But the government made it seem that way and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11th, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003.
Um, I, I myself am pretty much against war so, especially to make a preemptive strike, I was against that. Um, and I think that it's, the war in Iraq is kind of, a, a repeat in many ways of um, the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes that they have made with. I mean the, a tremendous amount of American soldiers have died. 
And that's horrible and, what they were doing is that they were taking out, they were removing the country's government and I really don't think the government, the American government was prepared for the um, what, for the aftermath and the void of power and the chaos that was going to occur. Um, and here, and the government, and so the United States is removing the Iraqi government and, they are trying to implant a democratic government and it's kind of a similar thing they were trying to do in Vietnam, they were trying to push out Communists and and, and uphold or implement, implement and uphold democracy, and, and it, and it, and the government, and the US government should have known that it was going to be a long and hard ordeal that probably wasn't, that was not going to be a clear clear victory like it wasn't like it wasn't a clear. I mean it was more of a, it was more of a loss in Vietnam because because, um, because there because there are there are, no matter how many people may have supported, no matter how many Iraqis may have wanted the US to come in and no matter how many Vietnamese may have wanted the US to come in there's going to be a large number of insurgents and its hard to put them down when when you’re not fighting an actual army. You’re fighting the citizens, the specific citizens in the country and so, so I think that I think that the government, so first of all I think that we shouldn't have gotten into into war cause I'm against it in pretty much all cases and but if you are going to go to war with the country you need to be, you need to plan for all possible outcomes. I think the government was not as prepared as it should have been, I mean worst, and either for what would, really not plan for what would happen once once they removed the the Iraqi government and, I mean we’re still there today and almost the end of 2006 and we’re still, um, many American troops are still dying and and they're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and Iraqi, and the Iraqi police forces to be able to police their own country and it’s a long process and I just think that that, that the US government in a way tried to, well they weren’t prepared themselves but in a way try to deceive the American people in making them think it would be a, a, a short successful stay in Iraq and, I mean we shouldn’t, we're kinda, we're naïve for believing that because it takes a number of years to implement a new form of government and to and for it to become successful, I mean in our own country, democracy was a long struggle and to be able to get to the powerful government we are today was a long struggle and there was, there was lots of tension and there was civil war and, um, its just not an easy thing to do and I think the government, the US government made it seem like a relatively easy thing to do and, um, so, and so, let’s see, the war in Iraq. Well, that’s, no that’s, no that’s a difficult decision to make because, that was, well that was kind of my feeling I guess in the election, like the Presidential election of 2004 when I was thinking about who I would vote for if I could vote and one of, um, one of my reasons that I probably would have voted for George Bush was to let him finish what it was that he started and, and so I mean once, its really hard cause once you go in there and we’ve been in there for so long how can we abandon these people, I mean we’re the ones that took away their government and and, and their way of life so how can we abandon them, abandon them now so, so it’s probably something that we should (coughs) excuse me, try to see to its finish but then again there’s also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties and, and, and how, and how much is is too much to to to keep risking for for a free democratic Iraq, I mean, going back to the whole reason for invading Iraq, I mean if we’re, if we’re, if we’re invading Iraq and making it it a democratic nation why is it just Iraq, why aren’t we doing this to all these other countries and I think the big reason for that is, is, is the oil issue, and this is where we are getting our oil from, and it’s usually all about money and controlling resources, I mean because another one of the predispositions is before going into war was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, and no weapons of mass destruction were ever actually found, and yet places like North Korea we actually knew that they had weapons of mass destruction and we are not making any attacks against them, so I don’t think the us government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making there decisions. Let’s see, um, I just hope that it ends soon, and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

I think it's important to remember that marriage equality is a fundamental human right. It's about love, commitment, and the ability to build a family. Denying same-sex couples the right to marry is discriminatory and unjust. 

It's not a matter of personal preference; it's about equality and fairness. There is growing scientific evidence that sexual orientation is a complex interplay of biological and environmental factors, and it's not a choice. 

Marriage is a deeply personal and private matter. It should be celebrated and supported, not dictated by government interference or societal norms. Everyone deserves the right to love and be loved, and to have their relationships recognized and respected.

I feel like the war has been going on for far too long. I think the purpose was good at the beginning, meaning to restore democracy in another country. But I think we've long since lost sight of that purpose, and now we're maybe just doing it for the sake of doing it, just to prove that we're some sort of superpower in the world. I just think also maybe the motives were originally questionable, dealing with Um, George Bush's father's previous quarrels with Saddam Hussein. So I think, Um, I think the original motivation if it was to give democracy to a country that didn't have a fair political system, then that would be a fair motivation. If there were any personal matters in it, I don't think it would have been fair. But I do think it's been drawn out. Um, I think we got our purpose across in the first couple of months just starting the war. I think that was a statement in and of itself. But the fact that it has gone on for over a year, several years, I just think it's way too drawn out.

Um, yeah, I think, Um, I mean, if our purpose was to give democracy to a country that was ruled by a tyrant, I think that's a just purpose, and that's good reason for the war. But I don't think, I think our reason over time has been deteriorated and misconceived, just like it seems that we're still at war for the purpose of going to war, and we don't want to come out of this thing without a decisive end, a victory or what not.

Um, yeah, I do think it has gone on long enough, and it should stop. I mean, there comes a point when their government, their officials are gonna have to fend for themselves anyway, and I think that time has come. We've long since been draining our own economy, spending billions of dollars when we have our own wars on our own turf such as poverty and whatnot that we should be spending that money on. I think it's a drain on our economy for a purpose that's long since been drawn out.

Yeah, I mean they're spending billions and billions of dollars, and war is not something that should be in our budget for the long term. There are things obviously such as poverty or internal improvements, you know, Um, public roads or anything dealing with schools. We certainly have a lot of problems funding things like that. Healthcare that I think that money could be much better spent on. Right now that money's being spent to have some of our own citizens killed in a foreign country at a war that we've lost the cause for.

I think that's it.

I can ask a clarifying question? Um, it was prevented because someone went online and found that there was like... Okay, ok. Um. No, I don't think that's an invasion of privacy. On sites like Myspace, I mean if you post information on the internet, it's pretty much available for everyone to see. And I understand on Myspace, you know you have to have someone else be a member in order to see someone's profile. You might need to, you know, be their friend or something like that. But if that's the case, you've accepted that person as your "friend" so they can see it, you're giving them permission to see your profile. So, I mean anytime you put information on the internet, you pretty much have to understand that a lot of people are going to see that. So if I think that was actually good, that somebody saw that and was able to prevent a life from being lost.

Hum, um, that's tough because, I mean obviously you can't have one person sitting around all day looking at everybody's different profiles, of all the students in the school to prevent that. Um, I mean, I don't think it would really be right to go and have somebody's job be to look at peoples profiles, but I guess it all depends on like what situation they came across that profile. So I don't really know.

Sure, um, well, um, like, I mean, I I don't have a Myspace personally but I have a Facebook. I do, it bothers me that I know that there's creepy people out there who can see things about me. And I saw something on tv once that was about this, um, this man who just, he was just trying to prove how he can get information so easily, and he went onto this girls profile and got her screen name right away and was talking to her on instant messenger in like you know less than a minute and got her to meet with him. And I mean personally I certainly wouldn't meet with someone, but I have had people in my classes who I don't recognize their screen names but they IM me and they know that it's me, and it's hard because you think that they know your interests, they know what you look like, sometimes if you put your class schedule they know where you are during the day, who your friends are, they pretty much know a lot about you, all sorts of photos, and I tried to limit what I put up there, but at the same time, the whole point I think, the reason I have one is so you know I can communicate with some of my friends. Hum, uh, well, I heard my roommate was telling me that her, um, high school she, there was this whole issue about how students were banned from having Myspace by the school, and that struck me as a little bit strange, like I wasn't sure how, how high school officials had the power to tell their students that they weren't allowed to have a Myspace. We only have this and then one more time that I need to talk about the Iraq War. I mean I feel hypocritical talking about it, I mean I hate to say, you know, I hate to join the bandwagon of people who are like, "Oh, I was against it from the beginning." Um, I was, but like it's not really important anymore. Because the general consensus everywhere was that it was a bad idea except within the administration because they don't want to admit they were wrong. And um, I mean you just have to look at like the recent polls. Um, they've done United States polls, they've done Iraqi polls, they've done global polls, and I mean no, about seventy-five to eighty percent of the population of the world thinks that it was a bad idea. Eighty percent of Iraqis, um, seventy percent of the troops that are over there, like the U.S. troops that are over there right now, think it was a dumb idea and that we should pull out within the year. Um, I don't know, it's just been a complete disaster from before we even came in. It was already a disaster, and now pulling out is also going to be a disaster. There's really no easy way to go about really anything involving the Middle East anymore. Um, I mean I think it's just the culture clash between like the United States and the Middle Eastern states. I mean it's just too big of a gap, and for like this administration or previous administrations to understand. And they think that they can just like bring democracy into an area where it shouldn't exist. Like that's not the way that, um, this totally different group of people would choose to run their lives. I mean sure Saddam was a bad guy, I don't think anyone's like arguing that he's not, but, I mean you have to weigh the pros and cons before you invade a country that's going to, you know, turn into just a complete disaster, just like quicksand from when we went over there. Um, I don't even know what to say about it. Um, I don't really see a reason at all to stay in there. Um, I mean, I'm sure the administration is thinking some hopeful ideas as to why it's better to stay in there, um, and you know the problems that might arise from us pulling out. I don't agree with them. I've yet to hear like a legitimate reason why we should stay in any longer than we should. Um, I mean if they want to do it gradually over the course of a year or maybe a little longer than a year, um, I guess I wouldn't really have a problem with that, but, I just don't see a reason why we shouldn't just leave now. Um, I mean I read this statistic a little while ago that eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year, and at least a quarter of them think that we should just leave now. And like these, these are the people that we're trying to save, like that we're trying to help. Telling us to leave. Um, you know, I think they might know better than that. And at least if we ask them, should we leave and they say yes, then you know it's not on us if something happens. You know if it completely goes to shit, we could be like, well we were going to stay in but you guys made the decision not to. Um, and then you know at least we'll, I mean if we decide to help out after that, we'll at least be the good guys. Kind of, not really, no. We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but, you know, it'll be better than you know where we are, where we stand right now. Um, yeah. Uh, no.

I feel that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. And it's not only towards women. I feel it has to do with the particular field of work that you're dealing with.  Overall, I feel women have it more difficult because of the glass ceiling. Even though there's supposed to be equality, most people have a hard time finding that they may have to work under a woman if they're a man, just because of how society has been raised for so long. So many times in the workplace, women will see a job they can reach and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't elect to promote them to that position just because historically, it's not seen that women are usually in the upper hands of the business world.  And um, I guess the same thing goes for men. And like other industries like fashion or being a parent at home. It's really uncommon to have a stay-at-home parent who's male. And um, a lot of times people look down upon that because society thinks, well, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the money maker of your family. Why are you staying at home? And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them and maybe the wife has the better job and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down upon that. And then in the fashion industry, um, a lot of times people won't really take males seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion um, like, I guess, have different styles of life. And so if you have the typical style of life and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, well, wait, how do I really know if like you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really don't know what our case is like, like these other guys. And so, depending on like what field of work you're in, I feel like there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. To change it is kind of more difficult because society like has a set mindset and obviously we have come a long way from like the 1800s and leaps and bounds, but change is really slow, so I feel that like if we continue working at the pace we are now because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world and it's a slow process, but it's happening and people are starting to accept it more. And just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, oh wait maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works. And um, then for like fashion people will be like, oh wait maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff, and so they do know like where I'm coming from. So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotypically stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um saying like the qualities of them, because if you force it people are going to resist, and I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that. So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist, and we've come a long ways and change takes time. Yes, um, well I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you go to have yourself like you work your way up into a CEO job even though you might not have the best grammar in the world and or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like well how do I know you're really what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right. So yeah, so like sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don't know, I guess that'd be another example. Um, not really.
