I would say yes because a lot of the things they do are very traditional, like they've done the same things for long periods of time, and it's good to be rooted in tradition, but it's also important to be adaptable to change. I guess a lot of Catholics believe they have to go to Church every week, and they're very strict on how things are done. And sometimes I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on people who don't follow the doctrine to a tee, and they don't accept people who aren't exactly perfect Catholics. They also don't accept people of other religions. For example, my dad was an Episcopalian, my mom was a Catholic, and they wouldn't marry my parents in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. And that's not really like being tolerant of other religions. We always learned to love others; that's a Catholic teaching, but it's hypocritical to say to love others and then not accept them in that way. So I feel like a lot of Catholic doctrine tells you to do things, but then the Catholic practice goes against it because it's so outdated, but they continue to stick with it anyway. 

I don't think that would necessarily influence it. I mean, I personally think that it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, but as I don't think that would necessarily deter them from their, like, pedophilic behavior, so because it's just a different realm, um, it might, but I probably don't think that that would be an issue. Um, well, I guess like people who molest children, probably would do that regardless of whether they had a spouse or not because it's a child which is different than a spouse. So if you're going to do something like that, you're probably going to do it whether or not you're married. Like, I don't think allowing priests to be married would prevent, um, those things from happening. I think that would probably happen regardless.

Um, I haven't made up my mind on this issue yet. So, I can't say if either side is right or wrong. But I do believe this is the trickiest topic we're facing today. This is because something so close to the separation of church and state and how to define marriage is very tricky to do without offending anyone. So, I don't know, I think that all civil unions, I don't know whether marriage should be looked at and defined by the government. Seeing as it is a sacrament, like considered... Well, people wouldn't get tax breaks or be looked at in any specific way by the government if they were baptized. And so, if you're married, I think they should just look at it as a civil union because that's what it is, it's two people. They shouldn't have separation of church and state; they shouldn't look into what kind of marriage it was. Two people got united together. So, and the fact that gay marriage, I mean, that would just... oh, two people you got a civil union.

Um, well, if all the states can come to a logical conclusion, then they should push to make it federal law. But a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is just ridiculous. It is something like the constitution shouldn't just be amended for something. I mean, it is a very big cause for certain people, but it's not large enough that it should be a constitutional amendment.

It's just not important enough to amend the constitution to define to ban gay marriage. Simply put. Uh, no.

I was raised in a Christian home, so homosexuality is kind of a grey area for me. I have a lot of gay friends, and I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, but I think it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but I feel each state should decide for itself rather than the president deciding for the entire country.

A lot of states are democratic and a lot are republican. Obviously, democratic states will push for gay marriage, and if you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about that position. If a state decides to legalize gay marriage, I don't think you're really in a place to disagree with that decision because you kind of chose to live there.

I think homosexuals should be given the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel like it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. 

I kind of already answered that, but I don't think Bush should be allowed to decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to the individual states to decide whether they want to legalize it. I don't agree with his ban on it. I just don't think Bush lives in every single state, so he shouldn't be able to decide how each state wants to run itself. So I think some things should be left up to each individual state. Plus, he's going to be out of office in like two years, and if a democratic president decides that he wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, it's just going to go back and forth. It should just be up to each individual state because they're the ones that are going to have to live with that decision, not the president.

I don't think so at all. Let me see, in my opinion, Myspace is a public thing, like a bulletin board. If you look at the definition, it's basically for posting things for the public to see.  If you post something on the internet, you have to realize that people will see it, whether it's school officials or not.  So, I think the school officials had every right to see it because even if they weren't doing it under the school's name, they could still access it from their homes. But when it comes to preventing school shootings, as long as it saves the lives of students, which is the responsibility of the school system, I think it's perfectly fine.

Let me see. If they go on the internet, like Myspace, just to see if students are drinking, smoking, or doing things they're not supposed to, they're specifically looking to catch students and get them in trouble, and that feels like an invasion of privacy. But if they're trying to save lives or make the school a better and safer place, I don't think it's an invasion at all.

Should I elaborate more on that?

Yeah, okay.  It's easier to express yourself in writing when you have more time.  Like I was saying, it is a public thing.  If a student posts something on Myspace and doesn't expect to get in trouble, that's ridiculous. I'm even worried about posting things on emails. If I have something negative to say about someone, I don't say it in an email because I'm afraid someone might see it. Everything comes back around nowadays.  

Like, if you do something as a college student, and then grow up to be an important person, they might find an email you sent. Once it's on the internet, it's always there, and there's no way to get out of it. You will get in trouble. I don't think it was an invasion of privacy because, like I said before, it's a public thing.

I don't think they should go on the internet just to catch students, but if they have something that leads them to make the school system safer, then I think it's fine. Other officials, like the police, can go on too. Parents drop their students off at school expecting a safe place. I've talked to a teacher about this. They say we have to do things like this because of things like lockdowns and drills, which are in reference to terrorist attacks. We had to be safe, and that kind of relates to school shootings because if someone were to come into the building, we had to be prepared. We practiced these things to make the school safer. That's what the school officials were doing in this case; they were just making it a safer place, preventing something bad from happening, like Columbine.

I think at first I supported the war because of 9/11, because it personally affected me. I was all for going over there and causing as much havoc as they did here. I think because it was such an emotional event, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long run. We kind of just went over there unprepared and without a plan. I really think it backfired on us.  I don't know, I was all for it at the time, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I think the people there, as long as they are fighting amongst themselves, they can't be fighting with us. Like, I don't think us being there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost just become indifferent to what happens over there with those people. I just don't care. I just think sometimes they're not human. I don't know, they fight with each other and they just can't do anything themselves. So I really don't care. We definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face. And it's also bad because war for them is very different than war for us. They're just savage when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out. And I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave, and that's really it. We were just more hype than anything else. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle. We pretty much just went over there looking for revenge, I think, and I think President Bush just went over there because the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. And also, I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. But at the time, I see where he was coming from. We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say ok, let's rebuild and that's it. So, I don't think we could have let it go. But I think we could have had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, like creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't have unity. They didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And I don't really have anything else to say. It's gone on definitely long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. Like we've made progress, but not enough to stay there. And I think no matter how long we stay there, once we leave, it's just gonna collapse. And we can't stay over there forever. So I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying there. No. Ok.

Okay. The war in Iraq. Well, to start from the beginning, I don't think the government was completely honest with the American people about the reasons for war. Before invading Iraq, I think there was, I think there was an attempt to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th when in reality one really didn't have that much to do with the other. But the government made it seem that way and played on the emotions of the American people in their outrage against the terrorist attacks of September 11th, 2001, and the invasion of Iraq started in 2003.
Um, I, I myself am pretty much against war so, especially to make a preemptive strike, I was against that. Um, and I think that it's, the war in Iraq is kind of, a, a repeat in many ways of um, the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes that they have made with. I mean the, a tremendous amount of American soldiers have died. 
And that's horrible and, what they were doing is that they were taking out, they were removing the country's government and I really don't think the government, the American government was prepared for the um, what, for the aftermath and the void of power and the chaos that was going to occur. Um, and here, and the government, and so the United States is removing the Iraqi government and, they are trying to implant a democratic government and it's kind of a similar thing they were trying to do in Vietnam, they were trying to push out Communists and and, and uphold or implement, implement and uphold democracy, and, and it, and it, and the government, and the US government should have known that it was going to be a long and hard ordeal that probably wasn't, that was not going to be a clear clear victory like it wasn't like it wasn't a clear. I mean it was more of a, it was more of a loss in Vietnam because because, um, because there because there are there are, no matter how many people may have supported, no matter how many Iraqis may have wanted the US to come in and no matter how many Vietnamese may have wanted the US to come in there's going to be a large number of insurgents and its hard to put them down when when you’re not fighting an actual army. You’re fighting the citizens, the specific citizens in the country and so, so I think that I think that the government, so first of all I think that we shouldn't have gotten into into war cause I'm against it in pretty much all cases and but if you are going to go to war with the country you need to be, you need to plan for all possible outcomes. I think the government was not as prepared as it should have been, I mean worst, and either for what would, really not plan for what would happen once once they removed the the Iraqi government and, I mean we’re still there today and almost the end of 2006 and we’re still, um, many American troops are still dying and and they're still trying to train the Iraqi troops and Iraqi, and the Iraqi police forces to be able to police their own country and it’s a long process and I just think that that, that the US government in a way tried to, well they weren’t prepared themselves but in a way try to deceive the American people in making them think it would be a, a, a short successful stay in Iraq and, I mean we shouldn’t, we're kinda, we're naïve for believing that because it takes a number of years to implement a new form of government and to and for it to become successful, I mean in our own country, democracy was a long struggle and to be able to get to the powerful government we are today was a long struggle and there was, there was lots of tension and there was civil war and, um, its just not an easy thing to do and I think the government, the US government made it seem like a relatively easy thing to do and, um, so, and so, let’s see, the war in Iraq. Well, that’s, no that’s, no that’s a difficult decision to make because, that was, well that was kind of my feeling I guess in the election, like the Presidential election of 2004 when I was thinking about who I would vote for if I could vote and one of, um, one of my reasons that I probably would have voted for George Bush was to let him finish what it was that he started and, and so I mean once, its really hard cause once you go in there and we’ve been in there for so long how can we abandon these people, I mean we’re the ones that took away their government and and, and their way of life so how can we abandon them, abandon them now so, so it’s probably something that we should (coughs) excuse me, try to see to its finish but then again there’s also the consideration of the astronomical amount of American casualties and, and, and how, and how much is is too much to to to keep risking for for a free democratic Iraq, I mean, going back to the whole reason for invading Iraq, I mean if we’re, if we’re, if we’re invading Iraq and making it it a democratic nation why is it just Iraq, why aren’t we doing this to all these other countries and I think the big reason for that is, is, is the oil issue, and this is where we are getting our oil from, and it’s usually all about money and controlling resources, I mean because another one of the predispositions is before going into war was that Iraq had weapons of mass destruction, and no weapons of mass destruction were ever actually found, and yet places like North Korea we actually knew that they had weapons of mass destruction and we are not making any attacks against them, so I don’t think the us government is being thorough enough or truthful enough in making there decisions. Let’s see, um, I just hope that it ends soon, and there will be peace there soon, but probably not.

I think it's important to remember that marriage equality is a fundamental human right. It's about love, commitment, and the ability to build a family. Denying same-sex couples the right to marry is discriminatory and unjust. 

It's not a matter of personal preference; it's about equality and fairness. There is growing scientific evidence that sexual orientation is a complex interplay of biological and environmental factors, and it's not a choice. 

Marriage is a deeply personal and private matter. It should be celebrated and supported, not dictated by government interference or societal norms. Everyone deserves the right to love and be loved, and to have their relationships recognized and respected.

Um, I think we got our purpose across in the first couple of months just starting the war. I think that was a statement in and of itself. But the fact that it has gone on for over a year, several years, I just think it's way too drawn out.

Um, yeah, I think, Um, I mean, if our purpose was to give democracy to a country that was ruled by a tyrant, I think that's a just purpose, and that's good reason for the war. But I don't think, I think our reason over time has been deteriorated and misconceived, just like it seems that we're still at war for the purpose of going to war, and we don't want to come out of this thing without a decisive end, a victory or what not.

Um, yeah, I do think it has gone on long enough, and it should stop. I mean, there comes a point when their government, their officials are gonna have to fend for themselves anyway, and I think that time has come. We've long since been draining our own economy, spending billions of dollars when we have our own wars on our own turf such as poverty and whatnot that we should be spending that money on. I think it's a drain on our economy for a purpose that's long since been drawn out.

Yeah, I mean they're spending billions and billions of dollars, and war is not something that should be in our budget for the long term. There are things obviously such as poverty or internal improvements, you know, Um, public roads or anything dealing with schools. We certainly have a lot of problems funding things like that. Healthcare that I think that money could be much better spent on. Right now that money's being spent to have some of our own citizens killed in a foreign country at a war that we've lost the cause for.

I think that's it.

I can ask a clarifying question? Um, it was prevented because someone went online and found that there was like... Okay, ok. Um. No, I don't think that's an invasion of privacy. On sites like Myspace, I mean if you post information on the internet, it's pretty much available for everyone to see. And I understand on Myspace, you know you have to have someone else be a member in order to see someone's profile. You might need to, you know, be their friend or something like that. But if that's the case, you've accepted that person as your "friend" so they can see it, you're giving them permission to see your profile. So, I mean anytime you put information on the internet, you pretty much have to understand that a lot of people are going to see that. So if I think that was actually good, that somebody saw that and was able to prevent a life from being lost.

Hum, um, that's tough because, I mean obviously you can't have one person sitting around all day looking at everybody's different profiles, of all the students in the school to prevent that. But then it becomes some sort of discrimination if they think, "Oh let's look at the bad kids and make sure they're not up to anything". Um, I mean, I don't think it would really be right to go and have somebody's job be to look at peoples profiles, but I guess it all depends on like what situation they came across that profile. Or was someone just randomly looking at peoples and just randomly happened to see that, or were they actually looking for, you know, some sort of evidence that the student was planning something. So I don't really know.

Sure, um, well, um, like, I mean, I I don't have a Myspace personally but I have a Facebook. I do, it bothers me that I know that there's creepy people out there who can see things about me. And I saw something on tv once that was about this, um, this man who just, he was just trying to prove how he can get information so easily, and he went onto this girls profile and got her screen name right away and was talking to her on instant messenger in like you know less than a minute and got her to meet with him. And I mean personally I certainly wouldn't meet with someone, but I have had people in my classes who I don't recognize their screen names but they IM me and they know that it's me, and it's hard because you think that they know your interests, they know what you look like, sometimes if you put your class schedule they know where you are during the day, who your friends are, they pretty much know a lot about you, all sorts of photos, and I tried to limit what I put up there, but at the same time, the whole point I think, the reason I have one is so you know I can communicate with some of my friends. I don't want to limit it too much so it's a tricky issue because I only accept people I know, I mean you never know really who can look at what, so.

Hum, uh, well, I heard my roommate was telling me that her, um, high school she, there was this whole issue about how students were banned from having Myspace by the school, and that struck me as a little bit strange, like I wasn't sure how, how high school officials had the power to tell their students that they weren't allowed to have a Myspace. And I don't know if that's really a privacy issue, but I think, I don't really know how they had the right to tell people that. That's the only other thought I can think of. 

Yes.

We only have this and then one more time that I need to talk about the Iraq War. I mean I feel hypocritical talking about it, I mean I hate to say, you know, I hate to join the bandwagon of people who are like, "Oh, I was against it from the beginning." Um, I was, but like it's not really important anymore. Because the general consensus everywhere was that it was a bad idea except within the administration because they don't want to admit they were wrong. And um, I mean you just have to look at like the recent polls. Um, they've done United States polls, they've done Iraqi polls, they've done global polls, and I mean no, about seventy-five to eighty percent of the population of the world thinks that it was a bad idea. Eighty percent of Iraqis, um, seventy percent of the troops that are over there, like the U.S. troops that are over there right now, think it was a dumb idea and that we should pull out within the year. Um, I don't know, it's just been a complete disaster from before we even came in. It was already a disaster, and now pulling out is also going to be a disaster. There's really no easy way to go about really anything involving the Middle East anymore. Um, I mean I think it's just the culture clash between like the United States and the Middle Eastern states. I mean it's just too big of a gap, and for like this administration or previous administrations to understand. And they think that they can just like bring democracy into an area where it shouldn't exist. Like that's not the way that, um, this totally different group of people would choose to run their lives. I mean sure Saddam was a bad guy, I don't think anyone's like arguing that he's not, but, I mean you have to weigh the pros and cons before you invade a country that's going to, you know, turn into just a complete disaster, just like quicksand from when we went over there. Um, I don't even know what to say about it. Um, I don't really see a reason at all to stay in there. Um, I mean, I'm sure the administration is thinking some hopeful ideas as to why it's better to stay in there, um, and you know the problems that might arise from us pulling out. I don't agree with them. I've yet to hear like a legitimate reason why we should stay in any longer than we should. Um, I mean if they want to do it gradually over the course of a year or maybe a little longer than a year, um, I guess I wouldn't really have a problem with that, but, I just don't see a reason why we shouldn't just leave now. Um, I mean I read this statistic a little while ago that eighty percent of Iraqis think we should be gone within the year, and at least a quarter of them think that we should just leave now. And like these, these are the people that we're trying to save, like that we're trying to help. Telling us to leave. Um, you know, I think they might know better than that. And at least if we ask them, should we leave and they say yes, then you know it's not on us if something happens. You know if it completely goes to shit, we could be like, well we were going to stay in but you guys made the decision not to. Um, and then you know at least we'll, I mean if we decide to help out after that, we'll at least be the good guys. Kind of, not really, no. We'll never be the good guys in the Middle East, but, you know, it'll be better than you know where we are, where we stand right now. Um, yeah. Uh, no.

I feel that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. And it's not only towards women. I feel it has to do with the particular field of work that you're dealing with.  Overall, I feel women have it more difficult because of the glass ceiling. Even though there's supposed to be equality, most people have a hard time finding that they may have to work under a woman if they're a man, just because of how society has been raised for so long. So many times in the workplace, women will see a job they can reach and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't elect to promote them to that position just because historically, it's not seen that women are usually in the upper hands of the business world.  And um, I guess the same thing goes for men. And like other industries like fashion or being a parent at home. It's really uncommon to have a stay-at-home parent who's male. And um, a lot of times people look down upon that because society thinks, well, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the money maker of your family. Why are you staying at home? And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise them and maybe the wife has the better job and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down upon that. And then in the fashion industry, um, a lot of times people won't really take males seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion um, like, I guess, have different styles of life. And so if you have the typical style of life and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, well, wait, how do I really know if like you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really don't know what our case is like, like these other guys. And so, depending on like what field of work you're in, I feel like there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S. To change it is kind of more difficult because society like has a set mindset and obviously we have come a long way from like the 1800s and leaps and bounds, but change is really slow, so I feel that like if we continue working at the pace we are now because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world and it's a slow process, but it's happening and people are starting to accept it more. And just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, oh wait maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works. And um, then for like fashion people will be like, oh wait maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff, and so they do know like where I'm coming from. So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotypically stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um saying like the qualities of them, because if you force it people are going to resist, and I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that. So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist, and we've come a long ways and change takes time. Yes, um, well I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you go to have yourself like you work your way up into a CEO job even though you might not have the best grammar in the world and or even though you might be intelligent, but you don't have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like well how do I know you're really what you're saying if you can't even put verbs and nouns together right. So yeah, so like sometimes just where you're from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don't know, I guess that'd be another example. Um, not really.

Um, and I think that if someone gets caught and gets cited with it than you know, for the purposes of job interviews and all sorts of things like that, um, those types of ramifications which are usually like the worst of having a drug charge would, I mean, usually the worst ramifications of having a drug charge, well, depending on the charge. Um, I mean so, I think it’s, it’s important cause I mean marijuana isn’t something that you just want out and out to be everywhere, all over the streets and stuff, Um, I mean for a variety of reasons, but there’s this whole like financial element to it as well. I mean, but they, they both have their adverse effects, and I mean they, I feel like when it comes to substances in general, like no two people really react the same way. I would say yes because a lot of the things they do are very traditional, like they've done the same things for long periods of time, and it's good to be rooted in tradition, but it's also important to be adaptable to change. I guess a lot of Catholics believe they have to go to Church every week, and they're very strict on how things are done. And sometimes I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on people who don't follow the doctrine to a tee, and they don't accept people who aren't exactly perfect Catholics. They also don't accept people of other religions. For example, my dad was an Episcopalian, my mom was a Catholic, and they wouldn't marry my parents in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. And that's not really like being tolerant of other religions. We always learned to love others; that's a Catholic teaching, but it's hypocritical to say to love others and then not accept them in that way. So I feel like a lot of Catholic doctrine tells you to do things, but then the Catholic practice goes against it because it's so outdated, but they continue to stick with it anyway. 

I don't think that would necessarily influence it. I mean, I personally think that it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, but as I don't think that would necessarily deter them from their, like, pedophilic behavior, so because it's just a different realm, um, it might, but I probably don't think that that would be an issue. Um, well, I guess like people who molest children, probably would do that regardless of whether they had a spouse or not because it's a child which is different than a spouse. So if you're going to do something like that, you're probably going to do it whether or not you're married. Like, I don't think allowing priests to be married would prevent, um, those things from happening. I think that would probably happen regardless.

Um, I haven't made up my mind on this issue yet. So, I can't say if either side is right or wrong. But I do believe this is the trickiest topic we're facing today. This is because something so close to the separation of church and state and how to define marriage is very tricky to do without offending anyone. So, I don't know, I think that all civil unions, I don't know whether marriage should be looked at and defined by the government. Seeing as it is a sacrament, like considered... Well, people wouldn't get tax breaks or be looked at in any specific way by the government if they were baptized. And so, if you're married, I think they should just look at it as a civil union because that's what it is, it's two people. They shouldn't have separation of church and state; they shouldn't look into what kind of marriage it was. Two people got united together. So, and the fact that gay marriage, I mean, that would just... oh, two people you got a civil union.

Um, well, if all the states can come to a logical conclusion, then they should push to make it federal law. But a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is just ridiculous. It is something like the constitution shouldn't just be amended for something. I mean, it is a very big cause for certain people, but it's not large enough that it should be a constitutional amendment.

It's just not important enough to amend the constitution to define to ban gay marriage. Simply put. Uh, no.

I was raised in a Christian home, so homosexuality is kind of a grey area for me. I have a lot of gay friends, and I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, but I think it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue, but I feel each state should decide for itself rather than the president deciding for the entire country.

A lot of states are democratic and a lot are republican. Obviously, democratic states will push for gay marriage, and if you live in a democratic state, you know how that state feels about that position. If a state decides to legalize gay marriage, I don't think you're really in a place to disagree with that decision because you kind of chose to live there.

I think homosexuals should be given the same opportunities as heterosexuals, so I feel like it should be legalized based on the discretion of each state. 

I kind of already answered that, but I don't think Bush should be allowed to decide that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to the individual states to decide whether they want to legalize it. I don't agree with his ban on it. I just don't think Bush lives in every single state, so he shouldn't be able to decide how each state wants to run itself. So I think some things should be left up to each individual state. Plus, he's going to be out of office in like two years, and if a democratic president decides that he wants to lift the ban on gay marriage, it's just going to go back and forth. It should just be up to each individual state because they're the ones that are going to have to live with that decision, not the president.

I don't think so at all. Let me see, in my opinion, Myspace is a public thing, like a bulletin board. If you look at the definition, it's basically for posting things for the public to see.  If you post something on the internet, you have to realize that people will see it, whether it's school officials or not.  So, I think the school officials had every right to see it because even if they weren't doing it under the school's name, they could still access it from their homes. But when it comes to preventing school shootings, as long as it saves the lives of students, which is the responsibility of the school system, I think it's perfectly fine.

Let me see. If they go on the internet, like Myspace, just to see if students are drinking, smoking, or doing things they're not supposed to, they're specifically looking to catch students and get them in trouble, and that feels like an invasion of privacy. But if they're trying to save lives or make the school a better and safer place, I don't think it's an invasion at all.

Should I elaborate more on that?

Yeah, okay.  It's easier to express yourself in writing when you have more time.  Like I was saying, it is a public thing.  If a student posts something on Myspace and doesn't expect to get in trouble, that's ridiculous. I'm even worried about posting things on emails. If I have something negative to say about someone, I don't say it in an email because I'm afraid someone might see it. Everything comes back around nowadays.  

Like, if you do something as a college student, and then grow up to be an important person, they might find an email you sent. Once it's on the internet, it's always there, and there's no way to get out of it. You will get in trouble. I don't think it was an invasion of privacy because, like I said before, it's a public thing.

I don't think they should go on the internet just to catch students, but if they have something that leads them to make the school system safer, then I think it's fine. Other officials, like the police, can go on too. Parents drop their students off at school expecting a safe place. I've talked to a teacher about this. They say we have to do things like this because of things like lockdowns and drills, which are in reference to terrorist attacks. We had to be safe, and that kind of relates to school shootings because if someone were to come into the building, we had to be prepared. We practiced these things to make the school safer. That's what the school officials were doing in this case; they were just making it a safer place, preventing something bad from happening, like Columbine.

I think at first I supported the war because of 9/11, because it personally affected me. I was all for going over there and causing as much havoc as they did here. I think because it was such an emotional event, we overlooked a lot of things and didn't really think about the long run. We kind of just went over there unprepared and without a plan. I really think it backfired on us.  I don't know, I was all for it at the time, but now I'm very against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. I think the people there, as long as they are fighting amongst themselves, they can't be fighting with us. Like, I don't think us being there is going to do anything if they can't even get along with themselves. So, unfortunately, because of 9/11, I've almost just become indifferent to what happens over there with those people. I just don't care. I just think sometimes they're not human. I don't know, they fight with each other and they just can't do anything themselves. So I really don't care. We definitely went over there unprepared. We didn't know what we were going to face. And it's also bad because war for them is very different than war for us. They're just savage when it comes to war, and I don't think they're looking to better their country. I just think they're looking to get us out. And I think that should be fine for us. I think we should just leave, and that's really it. We were just more hype than anything else. I don't think we were thinking rationally about what this could lead to or how they would react if we went in there and tried to change their whole lifestyle. We pretty much just went over there looking for revenge, I think, and I think President Bush just went over there because the people wanted to go over there because of what happened. And also, I think he kind of took it upon himself to just declare war on Iraq. But at the time, I see where he was coming from. We really didn't have a choice but to declare war on Iraq because they can't just do that and then us just say ok, let's rebuild and that's it. So, I don't think we could have let it go. But I think we could have had a better plan of what we were going to do. I don't think they were very clear on what we were supposed to do in terms of, I guess, like creating order. And I don't know, I just think that they didn't have unity. They didn't know what they were going in there for. So I think that would have helped us out a lot more. But like I said, I thought it was all emotion and anger that we went in there with, so that's what we created in turn. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. I honestly think they're always going to be like that. And I don't really have anything else to say. It's gone on definitely long enough. I don't think we're making enough progress. Like we've made progress, but not enough to stay there. And I think no matter how long we stay there, once we leave, it's just gonna collapse. And we can't stay over there forever. So I think we're just hurting ourselves by staying there. No. Ok.

I think in some ways the Catholic Church does need to change. Their views, I think a lot of the time the Catholic Church isn't very accepting, for example, of things like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. I know they have very strong views on these issues, and that's fine, but some of their views seem a little old-fashioned to me. So I think if they could adapt to some newer ways of thinking, they wouldn't worry about losing followers.

I've heard that a lot of people are starting to turn against the Catholic Church because of their views on these issues. People are starting to disagree with them on certain subjects. I think they feel that the Catholic Church has the wrong view on things.

For example, the Catholic Church is against abortion, so if you were for abortion, you might not be comfortable following a church that teaches it to be completely wrong and that you're going against it. The same goes for gay marriage and things like that. We only have this and then one more time that I need to talk about the Iraq War. Um, yeah, I mean, I feel hypocritical talking about it. I feel that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States, and it's not just against women. It also has to do with the particular field of work you're in. Overall, I feel women have it harder because of the glass ceiling. Even though there's supposed to be equality, many people have a hard time accepting that they might have to work under a woman if they're a man, simply because of how society has been raised for so long. 

So, in the workplace, women often see jobs they're qualified for, but maybe the board won't promote them because historically, women aren't usually seen in upper management positions in the business world.

I think the same goes for men, though. Like, in industries like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent, it's really uncommon for a male to be the one staying at home. And a lot of times, people look down on that because society thinks, 'Oh, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the breadwinner of your family. Why are you staying at home?' And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and raise them, and maybe the wife has the better job, and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down on that.

And then in the fashion industry, a lot of times people won't really take men seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion have different lifestyles. And so if you have the typical lifestyle and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, 'Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really know our case like these other guys.' 

So, depending on the field of work you're in, I feel like there's definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S.  To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset, and obviously, we've come a long way from the 1800s and leaps and bounds. But change is really slow, so I feel that if we continue working at the pace we are now, because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world and it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. And just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, 'Oh wait, maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works.' And, and for like fashion people will be like, 'Oh wait, maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff.' And so they do know like where I'm coming from.

So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um saying like the qualities of them because if you force it people are going to resist, and I feel that we’re kind of at a good balance where it’s starting to become enforced like that. So I don’t really know if there’s anything that we can do right now that isn’t already being done because if you do it too fast it’s like people will resist and we’ve come a long ways and change takes time. 

Yes. Um, well, I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you go on to have yourself, like you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world and, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don’t have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like, 'well how do I know you’re really what you’re saying if you can’t even put verbs and nouns together right.' So yeah, so like sometimes just where you’re from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don’t know, I guess that’d be another example. Um, not really.

I just think also maybe the motives were originally questionable, dealing with George Bush’s father’s previous quarrels with Saddam Hussein. So I think if the original motivation was to give democracy to a country that did not have a fair political system, then that would be a fair motivation. If there were any personal matters in it, I do not think it would have been fair. But I do think it’s been drawn out. Um, I think we got our purpose across in the first couple months just starting the war, I think that was a statement in and of itself. But the fact that it has gone on for over a year, several years, I just think it’s way too drawn out.

I think if our purpose was to give democracy to a country that was ruled by a tyrant, that’s a just purpose, and that’s good reason for the war. But I don’t think our reason over time has been deteriorated and misconceived. Just like it seems that we’re still at war for the purpose of going to war, and we don’t want to come out of this thing without a decisive end, a victory or what not.

Yeah, I do think it has gone on long enough, and it should stop. I mean there comes a point when their government, their officials are gonna have to fend for themselves anyway, and I think that time has come. We’ve long since been draining our own economy, spending billions of dollars when we have our own wars on our own turf such as poverty and what not that we should be spending that money on. I think it’s a drain on our economy for a purpose that’s long since been drawn out.

Yeah, I mean they’re spending billions and billions of dollars, and war is not something that should be in our budget for the long term. There are things obviously such as poverty or internal improvements. You know, um, public roads or anything dealing with schools. We certainly have a lot of problems funding things like that. Health care that I think that money could be much better spent on. Right now that money’s being spent to have some of our own citizens killed in a foreign country at a war that we’ve lost the cause for.

I think that’s it.

We only have this and then one more time that I need to talk about the Iraq War. Um, yeah, I mean, I feel hypocritical talking about it. I feel that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States, and it's not just against women. It also has to do with the particular field of work you're in. Overall, I feel women have it harder because of the glass ceiling. Even though there's supposed to be equality, many people have a hard time accepting that they might have to work under a woman if they're a man, simply because of how society has been raised for so long. 

So, in the workplace, women often see jobs they're qualified for, but maybe the board won't promote them because historically, women aren't usually seen in upper management positions in the business world.

I think the same goes for men, though. Like, in industries like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent, it's really uncommon for a male to be the one staying at home. And a lot of times, people look down on that because society thinks, 'Oh, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the breadwinner of your family. Why are you staying at home?' And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and raise them, and maybe the wife has the better job, and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down on that.

And then in the fashion industry, a lot of times people won't really take men seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion have different lifestyles. And so if you have the typical lifestyle and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, 'Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really know our case like these other guys.' 

So, depending on the field of work you're in, I feel like there's definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S.  To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset, and obviously, we've come a long way from the 1800s and leaps and bounds. But change is really slow, so I feel that if we continue working at the pace we are now, because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world and it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. And just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, 'Oh wait, maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works.' And, and for like fashion people will be like, 'Oh wait, maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff.' And so they do know like where I'm coming from.

So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um saying like the qualities of them because if you force it people are going to resist, and I feel that we’re kind of at a good balance where it’s starting to become enforced like that. So I don’t really know if there’s anything that we can do right now that isn’t already being done because if you do it too fast it’s like people will resist and we’ve come a long ways and change takes time. 

Yes. Um, well, I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you go on to have yourself, like you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world and, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don’t have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like, 'well how do I know you’re really what you’re saying if you can’t even put verbs and nouns together right.' So yeah, so like sometimes just where you’re from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don’t know, I guess that’d be another example. Um, not really.

I was raised in a Christian home, so homosexuality is kind of a grey area for me. I have a lot of gay friends, and while I don't necessarily agree with that lifestyle, I think it should be legalized. I don't think it should be a national issue. However, I feel as though each state should decide for themselves rather than having the president decide for the entire country.

I don't think you're necessarily in a place to disagree with that decision if a state decides to legalize gay marriage, because you kind of chose to live there.

It should just be up to each individual state because they're the ones that are going to have to live with that decision, not the president.

I feel like the war has been drawn out far too long. I think the initial purpose was good, meaning to restore democracy in another country. If there were any personal matters in it, I do not think it would have been fair. But I do think it’s been drawn out. Um, I think we got our purpose across in the first couple months just starting the war, I think that was a statement in and of itself. But the fact that it has gone on for over a year, several years, I just think it’s way too drawn out.

I think if our purpose was to give democracy to a country that was ruled by a tyrant, that’s a just purpose, and that’s good reason for the war. But I don’t think our reason over time has been deteriorated and misconceived. Just like it seems that we’re still at war for the purpose of going to war, and we don’t want to come out of this thing without a decisive end, a victory or what not.

Yeah, I do think it has gone on long enough, and it should stop. I mean there comes a point when their government, their officials are gonna have to fend for themselves anyway, and I think that time has come. We’ve long since been draining our own economy, spending billions of dollars when we have our own wars on our own turf such as poverty and what not that we should be spending that money on. I think it’s a drain on our economy for a purpose that’s long since been drawn out.

Yeah, I mean they’re spending billions and billions of dollars, and war is not something that should be in our budget for the long term. There are things obviously such as poverty or internal improvements. You know, um, public roads or anything dealing with schools. We certainly have a lot of problems funding things like that. Health care that I think that money could be much better spent on. Right now that money’s being spent to have some of our own citizens killed in a foreign country at a war that we’ve lost the cause for.

I think that’s it.

We only have this and then one more time that I need to talk about the Iraq War. Um, yeah, I mean, I feel hypocritical talking about it. I feel that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States, and it's not just against women. It also has to do with the particular field of work you're in. Overall, I feel women have it harder because of the glass ceiling. Even though there's supposed to be equality, many people have a hard time accepting that they might have to work under a woman if they're a man, simply because of how society has been raised for so long. 

So, in the workplace, women often see jobs they're qualified for, but maybe the board won't promote them because historically, women aren't usually seen in upper management positions in the business world.

I think the same goes for men, though. Like, in industries like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent, it's really uncommon for a male to be the one staying at home. And a lot of times, people look down on that because society thinks, 'Oh, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the breadwinner of your family. Why are you staying at home?' And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and raise them, and maybe the wife has the better job, and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down on that.

And then in the fashion industry, a lot of times people won't really take men seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion have different lifestyles. And so if you have the typical lifestyle and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, 'Well, how do I really know if you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really know our case like these other guys.' 

So, depending on the field of work you're in, I feel like there's definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S.  To change it is kind of more difficult because society has a set mindset, and obviously, we've come a long way from the 1800s and leaps and bounds. But change is really slow, so I feel that if we continue working at the pace we are now, because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world and it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more. And just as men who are stay-at-home dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, 'Oh wait, maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works.' And, and for like fashion people will be like, 'Oh wait, maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff.' And so they do know like where I'm coming from.

So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um saying like the qualities of them because if you force it people are going to resist, and I feel that we’re kind of at a good balance where it’s starting to become enforced like that. So I don’t really know if there’s anything that we can do right now that isn’t already being done because if you do it too fast it’s like people will resist and we’ve come a long ways and change takes time. 

Yes. Um, well, I guess they're probably also discriminated against each other depending on the type of job you have or like where you're from. Like if you grew up on a farm and your grammar maybe isn't the best, but you are extremely intelligent and you go on to have yourself, like you work your way up into a CEO job, even though you might not have the best grammar in the world and, or even though you might be intelligent, but you don’t have the best grammar in the world, other men might look down upon you and be like, 'well how do I know you’re really what you’re saying if you can’t even put verbs and nouns together right.' So yeah, so like sometimes just where you’re from can discriminate against you, and like from gender to gender, and I don’t know, I guess that’d be another example. Um, not really.

Well, I understand they didn't legalize it, they decriminalized it. Um, which took it down from a criminal offense to, uh, to more of like a traffic ticket. But at the same time there is an argument that, um, I mean it costs a lot to arrest people and to bring them in and to book them and to house them and then to let them go and then it costs a lot you know to have them come into court once, maybe twice, maybe three times and then appoint a public defender and then you have to pay the judge and then the state attorney’s office has to pick up the charge and basically press the charges. I mean all of that stuff costs a lot to do, and um, I mean, so, when you’re looking at municipalities that are financially in trouble, I mean a lot of them just philosophically aren’t willing to make that kind of concession, even if it would free up a lot of money for them. Why it shouldn’t necessarily, well no, I mean I, I don’t know how I would feel about, well because if it were totally like legalized I guess you could make it like cigarettes where it could be sold in gas stations and people would be smoking it everywhere, then I mean, I guess a lot of people would be like smoking and driving, and um, it still is like taboo in our society, in a lot of places and a lot of contexts, uh, to smoke marijuana, so, to have it out in the open like that, I feel like it would just be awkward to a lot of people. The volume on the microphone is kind of low, um, I don’t really know, um, I think in general alcohol has more debilitating effects on your motor skills, um, but I think in general marijuana for a lot of people has a more adverse effect on their lifestyle as opposed to just their decision making motor skills. I mean, but they, they both have their adverse effects, and I mean they, I feel like when it comes to substances in general, like no two people really react the same way, I mean, and then people, some people have personalities that are just more normal and they just kind of go balls to wall with everything they have, and then some people know how to exercise moderation and then some people don’t, so it, I guess that makes it really hard to generalize about the substance when people react different ways, but I definitely think that they both have their own adverse effects, um, yeah, uh, no I don’t.

I don't think you're necessarily in a place to disagree with that decision if a state decides to legalize gay marriage, because you kind of chose to live there.

It should just be up to each individual state because they're the ones that are going to have to live with that decision, not the president.

I believe in individual liberty and personal choice. It's wrong to deny someone their rights based on something they can't control, something that is a part of who they are. Gay marriage should be a personal decision between two people who love each other.

I think it's ridiculous that politics and government should interfere in such a personal matter. Marriage is a private affair, not a matter for the state. It's about love and commitment, not about legal definitions or political agendas.

There's a growing body of scientific evidence suggesting that sexual orientation is influenced by biological factors rather than solely by social influences. This further strengthens the argument that it's not a choice and should be respected.

It's hypocritical that a heterosexual couple can marry without public scrutiny, while a same-sex couple's decision to marry becomes a headline news story. Why should their love be treated any differently? Marriage equality is about fairness and recognizing that everyone deserves the same rights and protections under the law.

When you put something on the internet, it becomes public.  It's completely open to everyone. You can't control how people interpret it.

As an RA, I've dealt with this issue firsthand. Once you put something out there, it can shape people's opinions of you. If you're talking about violence or harmful acts, someone will take notice. You can't just put that out into the world. The internet is accessible to everyone.

For example, if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll see their bulletins.  In one instance, someone saw a concerning post online and brought it to the school's attention. The school had to act, even if the post was meant as a joke, because they couldn't risk anything happening.

It's hard to know what to take seriously online because some people joke around, but it's possible something could be a genuine threat. It could be a social experiment gone wrong or a serious indication of danger.

In a recent incident, someone overheard a conversation at school and reported it. When they investigated, they found concerning content on the student's Facebook page. What was meant as a joke took on a different meaning in light of the situation.

Ultimately, when you share something online, there's no real expectation of privacy. If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there. You can't control how people interpret it or what they take seriously.

While I don't believe school officials should be "friend"ing students on social media and snooping through their profiles, if something concerning is brought to their attention, they have a responsibility to take it seriously.

Yes, I do feel that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. 

And it's not just against women. I think it has to do with the particular field of work that you're dealing with. 

Overall, I feel that women have it more difficult because there's the glass ceiling, where even though equality is supposed to exist, most people have a hard time accepting that they might have to work under a woman if they're a man, just because of how society has been raised for so long. 

So, a lot of times in the workplace, women will see a job they can reach, and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't elect to promote them to that position just because historically it's not seen that women are usually in the upper hands of the business world.

And I guess the same thing goes for men. And in other industries like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent, it's really uncommon to have a male staying at home. 

And a lot of times people look down upon that because society thinks, oh well, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the money maker of your family. Why are you staying at home? And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise the children, and maybe the wife has the better job, and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down upon that.

And then in the fashion industry, um, a lot of times people won't really take males seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion, um, like I guess have different lifestyles. And so if you have the typical style of life and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, well wait, how do I really know if like you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really know what our case is like, like these other guys.

So, depending on like what field of work you're in, I feel like there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S.

To change it is kind of more difficult because society like has a set mindset, and obviously, we have come a long ways from like the 1800s and leaps and bounds. But change is really slow, so I feel that like if we continue working at the pace we are now, because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world, it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more.

And just as men who are stay-at-home Dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, oh wait, maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works.

And um, then for like fashion, people will be like, oh wait, maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff. And so they do know like where I'm coming from.

So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um, saying like the qualities of them because if you force it people are going to resist.

And I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that. So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist. And we've come a long ways and change takes time.

I believe in individual liberty and personal choice. It's wrong to deny someone their rights based on something they can't control, something that is a part of who they are. Gay marriage should be a personal decision between two people who love each other.

I think it's ridiculous that politics and government should interfere in such a personal matter. Marriage is a private affair, not a matter for the state. It's about love and commitment, not about legal definitions or political agendas.

There's a growing body of scientific evidence suggesting that sexual orientation is influenced by biological factors rather than solely by social influences. This further strengthens the argument that it's not a choice and should be respected.

It's hypocritical that a heterosexual couple can marry without public scrutiny, while a same-sex couple's decision to marry becomes a headline news story. Why should their love be treated any differently? Marriage equality is about fairness and recognizing that everyone deserves the same rights and protections under the law.

When you put something on the internet, it becomes public.  It's completely open to everyone. You can't control how people interpret it.

As an RA, I've dealt with this issue firsthand. Once you put something out there, it can shape people's opinions of you. If you're talking about violence or harmful acts, someone will take notice. You can't just put that out into the world. The internet is accessible to everyone.

For example, if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll see their bulletins.  In one instance, someone saw a concerning post online and brought it to the school's attention. The school had to act, even if the post was meant as a joke, because they couldn't risk anything happening.

It's hard to know what to take seriously online because some people joke around, but it's possible something could be a genuine threat. It could be a social experiment gone wrong or a serious indication of danger.

In a recent incident, someone overheard a conversation at school and reported it. When they investigated, they found concerning content on the student's Facebook page. What was meant as a joke took on a different meaning in light of the situation.

Ultimately, when you share something online, there's no real expectation of privacy. If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there. You can't control how people interpret it or what they take seriously.

While I don't believe school officials should be "friend"ing students on social media and snooping through their profiles, if something concerning is brought to their attention, they have a responsibility to take it seriously.

Yes, I do feel that gender discrimination is still an issue in the United States. 

And it's not just against women. I think it has to do with the particular field of work that you're dealing with. 

Overall, I feel that women have it more difficult because there's the glass ceiling, where even though equality is supposed to exist, most people have a hard time accepting that they might have to work under a woman if they're a man, just because of how society has been raised for so long. 

So, a lot of times in the workplace, women will see a job they can reach, and they have all the qualifications for it, but maybe the board won't elect to promote them to that position just because historically it's not seen that women are usually in the upper hands of the business world.

And I guess the same thing goes for men. And in other industries like fashion or being a stay-at-home parent, it's really uncommon to have a male staying at home. 

And a lot of times people look down upon that because society thinks, oh well, you're the male, you should be out working, you should be the money maker of your family. Why are you staying at home? And it can be really hard on them because perhaps it's always been their dream to be with the children and help raise the children, and maybe the wife has the better job, and it's working out fine for them, but society looks down upon that.

And then in the fashion industry, um, a lot of times people won't really take males seriously if they're straight. I don't know if that really makes sense, but I guess it's because typically males who are into fashion, um, like I guess have different lifestyles. And so if you have the typical style of life and you're a male and you're in the fashion industry, people will be like, well wait, how do I really know if like you know what fashion is for a woman? Like you don't really know what our case is like, like these other guys.

So, depending on like what field of work you're in, I feel like there is definitely gender discrimination in society in the U.S.

To change it is kind of more difficult because society like has a set mindset, and obviously, we have come a long ways from like the 1800s and leaps and bounds. But change is really slow, so I feel that like if we continue working at the pace we are now, because women are going up into higher positions and becoming CEOs and they're getting more accepted in the business world, it's a slow process, but it's happening, and people are starting to accept it more.

And just as men who are stay-at-home Dads, it's becoming more accepted because they realize, oh wait, maybe the female does have the better job or she wants to be the one that works.

And um, then for like fashion, people will be like, oh wait, maybe they're listening to like their friends that are females or their wives and stuff. And so they do know like where I'm coming from.

So I guess you kinda have to in a way promote it by putting out the good qualities of the people who are usually stereotyped against by not being too pushy, but um, saying like the qualities of them because if you force it people are going to resist.

And I feel that we're kind of at a good balance where it's starting to become enforced like that. So I don't really know if there's anything that we can do right now that isn't already being done because if you do it too fast it's like people will resist. And we've come a long ways and change takes time.

I believe in individual liberty and personal choice. It's wrong to deny someone their rights based on something they can't control, something that is a part of who they are. Gay marriage should be a personal decision between two people who love each other.

I think it's ridiculous that politics and government should interfere in such a personal matter. Marriage is a private affair, not a matter for the state. It's about love and commitment, not about legal definitions or political agendas.

There's a growing body of scientific evidence suggesting that sexual orientation is influenced by biological factors rather than solely by social influences. This further strengthens the argument that it's not a choice and should be respected.

It's hypocritical that a heterosexual couple can marry without public scrutiny, while a same-sex couple's decision to marry becomes a headline news story. Why should their love be treated any differently? Marriage equality is about fairness and recognizing that everyone deserves the same rights and protections under the law.

When you put something on the internet, it becomes public.  It's completely open to everyone. You can't control how people interpret it.

As an RA, I've dealt with this issue firsthand. Once you put something out there, it can shape people's opinions of you. If you're talking about violence or harmful acts, someone will take notice. You can't just put that out into the world. The internet is accessible to everyone.

For example, if you're friends with someone on Myspace, you'll see their bulletins.  In one instance, someone saw a concerning post online and brought it to the school's attention. The school had to act, even if the post was meant as a joke, because they couldn't risk anything happening.

It's hard to know what to take seriously online because some people joke around, but it's possible something could be a genuine threat. It could be a social experiment gone wrong or a serious indication of danger.

In a recent incident, someone overheard a conversation at school and reported it. When they investigated, they found concerning content on the student's Facebook page. What was meant as a joke took on a different meaning in light of the situation.

Ultimately, when you share something online, there's no real expectation of privacy. If you don't want it seen, don't put it out there. You can't control how people interpret it or what they take seriously.

While I don't believe school officials should be "friend"ing students on social media and snooping through their profiles, if something concerning is brought to their attention, they have a responsibility to take it seriously.
